Input.threadtitle: Perplexed by the reasons given for Real numbers
Input.posts:
Okay, it may be a few days before I get to the end of all three lectures, so if the issue is revisited after the first lecture, I apologize in advance. In the first lecture, we are told the rational numbers are inadequate for doing mathematics because they can't be used to solve all polynomial equations: And I haven't taken real analysis (or number theory, or complex analysis for that matter), but my high school math is shaken by this. I thought we'd need to 'step up' even from the Reals to the Complex numbers to provide solutions to ALL polynomial equations. I don't think I can express an answer for x in $$x^2+2 = 0$$, as an example. I'm completely behind the importance of moving up from $$\mathbb{Q}$$ to $$\mathbb{R}$$, and accept that I can express MORE answers with the Reals, and it certainly fills out our number line... but even the Reals doesn't provide for all the answers. (And if there's something on the 'other side' of Complex numbers, I'd love to know about those too!)
Upvotes:
1
That's interesting. It could be more appropriate to argue that the reals are adequate since the system is continous, continuity being defined as a a local property?
Upvotes:
1
I think moving from Integers to Rationals could be make because the Rationals are continuous. I believe it was said that the Rationals are continuous... but not complete. The Reals are complete, at least that's what I take from this week's lecture as far as I've listened. But I'm not convinced by the argument that we need the Real numbers over the Rationals because we can't provide a solution to all polynomial equations with the Rationals... 'cause we can't do it with the Reals either. (There's another thread and more of the 10B lecture I hope to digest while I wait for #2 son at the dojo tonight... so maybe one of those with sway me.)
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Rich, Saying the rationals are not sufficient to solve all polynomials does not imply that the reals are. The question was about the former - the inadequacy of the rationals. Step up to the reals, you can solve more equations. They in turn prove to be inadequate, so you extend to the complex numbers. And there, as far as polynomials go, the process closes off - Fundamental Theorem of Algebra. In fact, you can look at the whole series of number systems N to Z to Q to R to C as being extensions to solve more polynomial equations. Not sure how any of this should shake your high school math.

One can envision the exercise of counting right-ways across the line to a number, n, as being defined by n = q.d + r, where d is a divisor, q is the number of d's we count and r is a remainder, greater or equal to zero, and less than q. So in this set-up, n represents a distance from zero. For example, n = 12 when d = 3 means we counted 4 distances of length 3. The quotient-remainder theorem guarantees that this number is uniquely generated by a single combination of divisor and remainder. The foregoing is but one example of where something quite fundamental would breakdown.
